conclusion.title: Summary of Reflections and Vertical Stretches
conclusion.p: In this section we study transformations that stretch a function vertically, or reflect the function across one of the axes.

paragraphs.title: The Opposite
paragraphs.p: Thinking again of function notation as language, we know that the notation f(x) indicates an input called x and an output called f(x). Therefore, by replacing x with -x we are referring to the opposite of the input.
Likewise, if we replace f(x) with -f(x), we are referring to the opposite of the output.
In each case, -f(x) and f(-x) represent reflections:

li.p: Reflection of f(x) over the horizontal-axis
Reflection of f(x) over the vertical-axis

example.p: The function g(x) = x^3 - 5x^2 + 2 is graphed below.

paragraphs.p: To reflect g(x) over the x-axis, we would take the opposite of the output by multiplying the formula by -1.
The formula for this reflection is y \amp= -g(x) \amp= -x^3 + 5x^2 - 2 and it is graphed below:
To reflect g(x) over the y-axis, we would use the opposite of the input by evaluating g(-x).
The formula for this reflection is y \amp= g(-x) \amp= (-x)^3 - 5(-x)^2 + 2 \amp= -x^3 - 5x^2 + 2 and it is graphed below:

paragraphs.title: Vertical Stretch/Compress
paragraphs.p: In addition to reflecting a function, we can also stretch or compress a function vertically by multiplying the output a constant number a.

li.title: af(x) if a > 1
li.p: Vertically stretch the graph of f(x) by a factor of a

li.title: af(x) if 0 < a < 1
li.p: Vertically compress the graph of f(x) by a factor of a

note.p: In this section, we will not be exploring the transformation f(a*x) which represents a horizontal stretch or compression.
